title: 112_s3474
content: The Act titled "Protecting Students from Worthless Degrees Act" provides consumer protections for students. The Act defines "Federal financial assistance program" as programs authorized and funded by the Federal Government under specific laws. The term "institution of higher education" is defined in relation to specific programs authorized under title 10, United States Code. It refers to the definitions provided in the Higher Education Act of 1965 and the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 for different programs. The term "institution of higher education" is defined differently for various programs authorized under specific acts such as the Higher Education Act of 1965 and the Workforce Investment Act of 1998. The term "institution of higher education" under subparagraph (A)(v) and (A)(vi) refers to an educational institution that awards a degree or certificate and is located in any State. The term "State" includes various regions beyond the several States of the United States. The term "Freely Associated States" includes the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Republic of Palau. Institutions of higher education must meet certain requirements to participate in Federal financial assistance programs for programs preparing students for licensed professions. The completion of the program qualifies a student to take exams for entry into a recognized occupation or profession in the State where the institution is located. The institution offering the program must meet academically related pre-conditions for entry into the recognized occupation or profession in the State, provide timely placement for pre-licensure requirements, and comply with State licensing or professional mandates. The institution offering the program must meet specialized accreditation requirements through accreditation by a recognized agency to prepare students for work in the occupation or profession. The institution offering the program must meet specialized accreditation requirements through accreditation by a recognized agency to prepare students for work in the occupation or profession. If the program is in a pre-accredited, probation, or show cause status, the institution must establish to the satisfaction of the Secretary of Education that students are informed of the program's status before enrolling. The institution must inform students of the program's status and its impact on eligibility for assistance and entry into the profession. Disclosure of pre-accredited status in advertising is required. The institution must disclose its accreditation status and implications for students. It should also inform students if the program does not meet out-of-state or state residency requirements. The student's residency status is relevant, if applicable. This section will take effect 6 months after the enactment of the Act.
